A NOTE ON SUFFERING‚Ä¶ AND HEALING Can we avoid suffering? Like, avoid it altogether?
I‚Äôve had this conversation with Rabbis and a lot of deeper thinkers. And a life sans suffering doesn‚Äôt seem to be on the human curriculum.
But! If you lean into your suffering, you can lessen it. I‚Äôll take it.
Mitigating suffering goes like this: When we get even slightly enthusiastic about the cleansing and healing process, and we more willingly make an effort to work with our Soul, then we don‚Äôt suffer quite so severely. LEAN IN TO IT, babe. It‚Äôs a Dylan Thomas, ‚Äú Go willingly into the night ‚Äù kind of thing.
Anandamayi Ma (1896-1982) was a Bengali Saint. A beauty beyond beauties. She was gifted with precognition and faith healing. Her name translates to ‚Äújoy-permeated,‚Äù a title given to her by devotees for her perpetual state of divine joy.
Her teachings hit my heart. This one, though, is extra pure:
‚ÄúIt is by suffering that suffering is overcome, because without suffering very few would see the need for self-purification which leads to the unfoldment of our Immortal Self.‚Äù
‚Äì Anandamayi Ma
I find amazing relief in this paradox: ‚Äú It is by suffering that suffering is overcome. ‚Äù
When we let the suffering expand us, remake us, we become more Loving. Closer to our True Nature. And thus, ultimately‚Ä¶ we suffer less.
When the next challenge comes around it‚Äôs less terrifying, less‚Ä¶ offensive. It‚Äôs more manageable.
And in between prana breathing, and endurance, and problem-solving, and surrendering to the Infinite‚Ä¶we might find a few minutes of delight in there. And satisfaction that we‚Äôre transmuting the challenge into consciousness. Like healers do.
Or maybe‚Äîand this is equally enlightened and acceptable‚Äîmaybe it just sucks to the maximum point of sucking. When the suffering is almost intolerable. When you‚Äôve had all you think you can take. When you can‚Äôt comprehend what the f*cking ‚Äú gift in the pain ‚Äù might be‚Ä¶ there‚Äôs this:
May my suffering be of service.
At the very least.
May some good come of this.
If not for me, for someone else.
Some good.
At the very least.
May my suffering be of service.
It‚Äôs a sublime Buddhist approach to pain. When you‚Äôre in hell, the notion that your agony might have some Divine utility can help you endure. It‚Äôs a light ray of reason.
Either way‚Äîwhether you‚Äôve danced into the dark, or the demons dragged you through it‚Äîwhen you‚Äôre on the other side of it (and you will get to the other side), your wisdom is going to comfort someone else, perhaps many people, profoundly.
It‚Äôs a prayer, really: May this suffering be of service.
And so it is.

I played it on repeat driving, crying, yoga‚Äôing.
